title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: Private donors pledge $1 billion to CERN for future atom smasher
items.description: Benefactors agree to help support next-generation particle accelerator, but billions more are needed

items.title: U.S. senator asks <cite>Science</cite> to provide its coronavirus manuscripts, emails
items.description: Rand Paul has blasted government science officials and scientists over COVID-19’s origin

items.title: A simple policy corrected pervasive gender imbalance in Ph.D. awards at Dutch university
items.description: Eindhoven University of Technology’s success sets example for other institutions to follow, researchers say

items.title: AI may upend online studies critical to social science
items.description: Sophisticated bots risk contaminating surveys, games, and other approaches designed to shed light on human behavior

items.title: When creating images, AI keeps remixing the same 12 stock photo clichés
items.description: In a game of visual telephone, models converge on ecstatic sports wins, romantic nights in Paris, and other cultural chestnuts

items.title: Bell Labs 2.0? Silicon Valley bets on science with no strings attached
items.description: Billionaire-backed Episteme aims to free research from bureaucracy. History shows that’s a tall task

items.title: To reduce science’s carbon footprint, researchers in France reinvent work practices
items.description: Grassroots efforts explore what works—and where the tensions lie

items.title: CDC funds controversial hepatitis B vaccine trial in African newborns
items.description: Scientists question the value of the proposed study, which will investigate a vaccine long known to be efficacious and safe

items.title: <cite>Science</cite>’s 2025 Breakthrough of the Year: The unstoppable rise of renewable energy
items.description: Clean energy infrastructure is being deployed with unmatched scale and speed—and China is leading the way

items.title: Why are women more likely to get irritable bowel syndrome? New study provides clues
items.description: Cells in the guts of female mice respond to estrogen by increasing pain signaling, researchers find
